evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical preliminary phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations in the historical preliminary context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the historical preliminary data.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the historical preliminary phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The continued movement past the TRP despite communication implies coordination breakdown.
The presence of communication does not preclude breakdown in coordination.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, aligned crew communication and no coordination errors, or if mechanical failure caused the event, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication among crew and tug operators but also a procedural deviation with pushback continuing past the TRP and hitting a barrier, indicating a coordination breakdown rather than just procedural deviation (discriminator disc:R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION|R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN favors communication breakdown).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown; limited direct statements of communication failure.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 in the historical preliminary data.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear procedural deviation without communication issues or confirmed mechanical faults, the conclusion would change.
If environment or marking deficiencies were proven to cause the incident, the communication breakdown hypothesis would weaken.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators but also highlights a failure to stop at the TRP leading to collision, supporting a communication/coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation and environment factors

node.statement: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 withstands potential counterarguments and alternative explanations in the historical preliminary context.

assumptions: The communication and coordination described were insufficient to prevent the pushback beyond the TRP.
No mechanical failures were reported or observed in the evidence.
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or hardware failures, or if marking deficiencies caused the pushback beyond TRP, the communication breakdown explanation would be weakened.
If procedural deviations were clearly documented as the primary cause, the communication breakdown explanation would be less supported.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 shows active communication and coordination attempts among crew and tug operators, with the pushback continuing beyond the TRP despite these efforts, supporting the communication breakdown explanation and distinguishing it from procedural deviation, marking deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or marking deficiencies contributed more significantly to the event.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim.

assumptions: No mechanical fault was reported or detected in the evidence; operator procedural deviations are more consistent with the described events.
defeaters: If evidence of verified fault codes, bench checks, or repeated malfunctions indicating mechanical failure were found, this would change the assessment.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as of 12-25 during the hist_t0_prelim assessment.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, within the hist_t0_prelim scope.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA as of 12-25 during the hist_t0_prelim assessment.

assumptions: The TRP ground marking was present and visible as implied by the description of the nosewheel reaching it.
No evidence indicates the marking was deficient or not observable.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing or obscured, or if crew reported inability to see markings, the conclusion would change.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking and hit the blast barrier, indicating the marking was present and observable but the event was due to procedural deviation or control failure, not marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the marking was deficient or the pushback procedure was not followed

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution was observed and documented during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, within the hist_t0_prelim scope.

assumptions: Communication between crew and tug operators was effective and did not cause the deviation
Environmental markings were adequate and visible as no contrary evidence is provided
No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence indicates equipment faults
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or control malfunctions causing the pushback beyond the TRP
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, supporting environmental deficiency
If communication breakdown was documented preventing proper coordination

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution, showing the aircraft moved beyond the designated release point and hit a barrier. Evidence H1-H3 support that communication was maintained and the instructor took control, favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or environmental marking issues; assumptions made that communication was effective based on crew interactions.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t0_prelim dataset, including timing, operator actions, and environmental conditions.

assumptions: The presence of TRP markings and their visibility is assumed adequate based on H4.
No mechanical control failure occurred as no fault traces or bench checks are reported.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication failure preventing proper coordination, or environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, or mechanical faults caused loss of control, the conclusion would change.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during hist_t0_prelim on 12-25 is robust against potential defeaters or contradictory evidence.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings were present but possibly inadequate or not sufficiently visible to prevent the incident.
Procedural deviations alone do not fully explain the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the barrier.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clear and visible and the pushback procedural deviation was the sole cause, this would weaken the robustness of the environmental deficiency claim.
If further evidence indicated the tug or crew failed to comply with procedures despite adequate markings, the claim would be less robust.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP marking and hit a barrier, indicating the environmental/marking deficiency is robust against defeaters related to procedural deviations.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether procedural deviations or marking deficiencies primarily caused the event

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are available in sufficient quantity to guide operations safely

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters based on the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 during hist_t0_prelim.

assumptions: No mechanical fault codes or bench check results are available in the evidence.
Procedural deviations and communication details are sufficient to assess defeater resistance.
defeaters: If direct mechanical fault codes, equipment fault traces, or bench checks indicating control malfunction were presented, this would support mechanical failure resistance to defeaters.
If communication breakdown or environmental marking deficiencies were ruled out with stronger evidence, mechanical failure might be more plausible.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 describe human procedural actions and communication during pushback, with no direct indication of mechanical or control failure; the aircraft overrunning the TRP suggests procedural or operational issues rather than mechanical failure, thus contradicting the claim of mechanical/control failure resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence and reliance on procedural and communication history

If environmental markers were inadequate or not visible

node.statement: Crew members had sufficient time and opportunity to communicate and coordinate

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
